I think you missed the fucking point of her character arc. She was an obsessive mother who was so afraid to lose her son, she put a fucking spell on him to ensure he could never be harmed, even though it ultimately drove him insane from the inability to feel ANYTHING. She loved her son to the point she would do anything for him and she was devastated over his death, especially because she knew deep down she was partially to blame for it for turning him into the the obsessive jackass he had become. Because of that, she doubled down on it being Kratos's fault as a coping mechanism. Her arc was about getting over her grief and coming to terms with it being her own fault that Baulder was unhinged and trying to kill her, thus prompting Kratos to step in and save her. The fact that you think it was poorly handled means you don't understand the concept of grief or what it can make people do, let alone the empathy required to understand how it may affect others. I'd also say that you definitely aren't a parent but you don't even need to be to get understand it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>618358439
>We all memed the "see that mountain? you can go there" stuff, but atleast it was more or less true and it gave a sense of wonder.
The world of Elden Ring is not open like traditional open worlds. You have large areas connected by bootlenecks, it's basically Dark Souls 1, but with oversized areas.
There's no idea of following a geographic landmark, for example. Things are on the horizon for aesthetic purposes. In fact I think it is clear to any player that those things on the horizon are not "real", they are just simplified assets to represent the next "levels".
When you get past the Zelda BOTW tutorial an old man points to a characteristically shaped mountain and tells you to head in that direction. The idea is that you are going to venture into a world without borders and you can reach the mountains if you want. In Elden Ring if you try to follow a geographic landmark you will come to some border, usually in the form of a cliff that kills you on the spot if you fall.
I liked Elden Ring, played 120 hours before I finally got tired of it, but when people use its open world as an "example of how it should be done" I imagine that nobody has any idea what they are talking about.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I think EU3 has a more sound foundation than EU4 does. There are some things where EU4 does things better on this count (EU3 has quite a few mechanics built around historical determinism, like Great Divergence being bound to happen, and that divergence not arising from simulation of any particularities of Western Europe, even flaunting its own mechanics like innovativeness<->narrowmindedness -slider, but European technological advantage being hardcoded, whereas EU4 doesn't do a great job here with institutions and what not, but it at least tries), but overall I think EU3 goes for a more simulation-esque approach, which I think is better for its own sake because I like that sort of mechanics, but also because it's important for emergent narratives and alternative history RP.

Say, whereas EU3 tries to simulate population growth, EU4 has province development tied to the mana system: instead of provinces gaining population because of your good policies and booming trade, they gain what-kinda-sorta-maybe-translates-into-population... because the ruler is good at diplomacy and just wills "diplo development" (translating into what probably ought to be some thousands of citizens) into existence with press of a button? There are a lot of this sort of examples, I won't bother listing them all.

However, while at release I thought EU3:DW (particularly, Magna Mundi mod) was superior to EU4, I have changed my mind since. Despite the better foundation of EU3, EU4 is simply way more developed, particularly when it comes to playing non-European states, which increases the replayability quite substantially. If EU3 had gotten a couple of more expansions or EU4 a handful fewer (good expansions, Leviathan for example is kinda shit actually), as well as UI update and engine being patched to run better on modern systems, EU3 would be better, but that's not the case.

It's not awful in 2022 so you can give it a try, but I expect you to come back after a while.
